Chapter 3, section 7 on the seven kinds of eloquence, as in the previous section. When one takes the above as conditions and runs after various pleasing objects, one will definitely give rise to and attract karma that will lead to future existence.

That is to say, when the power of craving increases due to grasping, one runs after various good and bad objects in various ways. In order to obtain them, one accumulates much pure and impure karma that can lead to future existence. This karma, in the stage of arising, is collectively called the link of existence.
One should know that in this case, it is called existence because it can have future results based on this.
The elder explains:
Existence refers to the nature of existence. Therefore, the World-Honored One said:
Existence refers to the arising of future existence.
The nature of existence is the meaning of the arising of future results.
This explanation contradicts both reasoning and teachings, because existence should be no different from arising.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
If the body that is produced by the present existence is the same as the member of birth, then the members of dependent origination would be reduced in number.
If you say that present action is called existence because it is the cause of future existence, this also is unreasonable, because the substance of action is the present nature of existence.
Action is the present nature of existence and is able to be the cause of future existence. Therefore you cannot say that it is called existence only because it is a cause of existence.
If its own nature is existence, why is it necessary to give it the name existence?
Just as action is the cause that attracts retribution, and existence is the result of this cause. How can it be said that existence is given the name existence because it is a cause?
Even if it is granted that the name is given hypothetically, this does not mean that it does not have its own substance, because the cause and the result are of the same nature.
In order to prove this meaning, you should not cite this scripture, because there is a different recitation of the text of this scripture.
What is the different recitation?
There is a recitation that says:
Existence is that which causes the production of subsequent existence.
Even if we grant that the recitation is as you say, there is no disagreement with our interpretation, because in this case the name of the result is applied to the cause.
Because the existence of the cause of future rebirth is designated as future rebirth.
In order to illustrate this meaning, the World-Honored One said:
Grasping is the condition for existence.
Next, in order to show that existence is the condition for birth, this sÅ«tra is spoken.
Moreover, existence is the most proximate cause for birth, therefore a sÅ«tra says:

In order to show that karma has the most proximate cause for birth, therefore the effect is provisionally designated on the cause of existence of karma, this matter is inevitable.
Therefore, the concluding summary says: Grasping is the condition for existence, existence is the condition for birth.
Moreover, another sÅ«tra says, the Buddha told Ä€nanda:
The karma that brings about rebirth is called existence here.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra cited by the elder is not sufficient evidence for his own interpretation of existence.
Only the interpretation of existence by the Abhidharma masters accords with reason and the sÅ«tras, and is most excellent.
Existence is of two kinds: karma and karmic retribution.
Now, in this context, only karma-existence is taken, because it is explained as the proximate cause of the future result.
As stated in the previous variant sutra:
Existence means that which causes future rebirth.

Just as karma in the previous period is called the link of karmic formations, so karma in the future period is called existence. This shows that the causes of affliction and karma at the previous and future limits of cyclic existence are the same in attracting the result of karmic maturation.
The elder wrongly grasps the term existence as comprehensively including all existences, because the sutra does not specifically mention them.
That is to say, the Buddha generally speaks of existence as being of three kinds, therefore we know that the link of existence includes all existences.
If it were not so, the World-Honored One should have only spoken of it as karmic formations, or spoken of it as karma.
There is also a sutra that provides evidence, as a sutra says:
Existence means the arising of future rebirth.
Also, the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:
Existence is generally of three kinds: desire, form, and formless.
Also, the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:
Karma attracts future rebirth, which is called existence.
Another scripture says:
If there were no existence, could there be non-existence?
And so on, at length.
Therefore, grasping is the productive cause of action, and action is the contributory cause that makes grasping arise.
This is a brief statement of the tenets of the Sthaviras. Such statements are all not well-said. Although not specifically mentioned, they should be explained separately.

As it is said that consciousness, etc. are the conditions for name-and-form, etc., although the dependent origination of all in the three realms is generally discussed here, it is accepted that consciousness is said to be the condition for name-and-form, and name-and-form is said to be the condition for the six sense bases, based on the possibility of their occurrence.
In the same way, although not specifically mentioned here, it should be explained separately.
Namely, the karma of the three realms is said to be the name of the three realms.
What is the error in this?
If it were otherwise, it would include insentient things.
Namely, they themselves say:
If desire, form, and formless realms, such as craving, etc., increase in this dharma, this dharma is called the existence of the three realms as appropriate.
The attachment of the realm of desire and the realm of form increase in regard to dharmas that are not associated with mind, because they are not mentioned separately. They should be included,
but they are not accepted as such. Therefore, they are not included in the general statement.
If it is said that in this passage, sentient beings are discussed on the basis of ignorance, etc., although they are generally said to exist, they cannot be said to include insentient things.

Isnâ€™t it that in this passage, the order of evolution and involution and the order of the causes of affliction and action in producing birth are discussed? Therefore, although it is said in general that they exist, they are only discussed in accordance with what is appropriate, i.e., only unwholesome and wholesome contaminated action is discussed as the three kinds of existence of desire, form, and formlessness.
If the substance of this existence is like the member of action, why is it not discussed like that member under the name of action?
It has already been discussed under the name of action in the previous discussion of the meaning of the name action.
Why is it not called action?

In order to show that the cause that attracts subsequent existence is a kind of action and not all action is a cause of subsequent existence, the name existence is established and it is not called action.

Also, the name existence is well known in the holy teachings, as in the scripture on the seven existences, which says, Existence is due to action. Therefore their explanation is not good, because it does not distinguish the two.
To say that the name member of existence includes all existences is not a good explanation, because it contradicts reason and the teachings.
The scriptures they quote must be carefully examined.

First, as for the scripture on PÅ«raá¹‡a KÄÅ›yapa, it says that existence is the production of a later existence in the future. This has already been explained above, because there is a variant reading of this scripture and because the name of the result is applied to the cause.

Also, the scripture on the three existences that they quote does not contradict our interpretation, because it is a general question and answer. We do not say that all the aggregates of grasping are not called existence, but only that among the members of existence, action is the most important and therefore only action is called existence.

However, Ä€nanda asked in general about all existences and did not ask about the members of existence, and therefore the Buddha answered in general. Therefore the scripture they quote does not prove that the members of existence are, in general, the substance of all existences in the three realms.
Also, the two sutra passages that they cite are not contradictory, because they are spoken in a general way.
That is, the word â€œexistenceâ€ is used in a general way to refer to the existence of action and the existence of results of retribution, because they are both existent.
The first three realms of existence are generally referred to as existence and are said to be bound to the three realms because they are the results of all action.
Now, in order to reveal the differences of cause and effect, action and its results of retribution are said to be separate existences.

Or, the three realms of existence are generally referred to as one existence, because they are the many impure dharmas that are its doors. Now, only the action that attracts future existence and the result of retribution of future existence are generally referred to as existence.

Or, this scripture speaks of action that attracts future existence and future existence as existence. The scripture is correctly interpreting the action that attracts future existence and calls it the member of existence. How can you cite it as evidence that the general name is existence?
Therefore, after this passage, the scripture says:
If there is action bound to the realm of desire, can one establish the existence of the realm of desire?
No, World-Honored One.
In detail.

This shows that there must be karma, a place, a ripening, and a meaning. The dependent origination that is being discussed is the existence that will arise. In the state of arising, there is already the ripening of the body faculty and life faculty, which is called subsequent existence. In this way, existence is spoken of using the word existence, and the ripening that accompanies karma is not called existence, because it has no function in producing subsequent existence.
How can this holy teaching, which accords with the Abhidharma school, be used to prove their meaning?
Also, the MahÄpratÄ«tyasamutpÄda SÅ«tra that they cite says:
If there were no existence, could there be birth?
They also do not understand the meaning, so they bring it up again.

Here, the World-Honored One, when explaining the function of existence, grasping, taking effects, and bestowing effects, said: If there were no existence, could there be existence? He asked this to show that at the time when karma takes effects, if there were no present existence of karma, there would definitely be no meaning of being able to attract subsequent existence.
After this text, he also said:
If there were no existence, could there be birth?
This question is asked to show the time of the action and its result. It means that if past action exists or does not exist, there is definitely no present existence that is produced.
Or the meaning of the later text shows that even though action exists and has already taken its result, it must not be destroyed in order to have the meaning of producing present existence.
If there were no past, even though action has not yet been destroyed, it has already ceased and has no substance. How can it produce present existence?
But now the sutra says:
If it is said that this is because there is still the old following realm, this is just words without the principle of producing causes.
Therefore the meaning of this part of the sutra is different, and it is not a proof that there must be present action and present existence in order for there to be present results.
Present action and existence do not have present action as their result. How can it be that if there is no action, there is no existence?
Therefore this sutra is not a proof that the members universally include existence.

Herein, action existence is that which can exist, and if the existence of karmic retribution is that which is possessed, this possession is the meaning of the distinction in the future birth of the result of action.
Here, the correct explanation is that the existence that is able to be a condition is already established as the member of activity, as previously explained.
However, they further say:
Therefore, grasping is the cause of the activity that produces existence, and activity assists it to make existence arise.

This is not a correct explanation, because only the karma that is the member of existence has already been established many times in the above text, because the sutra only says that grasping is a condition for existence, and because only karma is accepted as a condition for existence.
How is it that the elder has not yet established the member of existence as only karmic existence, because he does not say that grasping is a condition for karmic maturation existence?
Therefore, the explanation that activity assists it to make existence arise is merely the playful words of a child in his own room, because it is not the Buddha's teaching.
The existence that accompanies karma has no ability to attract the arising of a later effect, because it has already been explained.

If you say that the power of the cause of birth existence is due to the power of the cause of retribution, then in the realm of form, when the cause of retribution is produced, there is no retribution, and since there is no power of assistance, it should not produce birth.
If you say that at that time there is the realm of retribution, this has already been refuted, and therefore it is not established.

If you admit that the power of the cause of birth existence is due to the power of the cause of retribution, then the member of existence is only existence as action, and only this existence as action has the power of grasping as a condition and can act as the condition for birth. The meaning of this is established.

The Ä€bhidharmikas also admit that in all states of ignorance, etc., the five aggregates are present, but they establish the members on the basis of the most outstanding one. The other inferior ones that are born together only act as companions. Therefore existence as retribution is not the basis for establishing the member of existence, because it is not outstanding.

Moreover, the Sthavira, his mind bound by anger and jealousy, reviles the sages of the past and explains that the condition of grasping only manifests existence as action as the member of existence. Therefore he asks himself:
The scriptures say that grasping is a condition for becoming. What is the reason for this?
They answer themselves,
saying that it is because it is directly seen that the present world directly sees that desire grasping is the cause for innumerable sentient beings creating various actions;
because of the grasping of precepts and observances, people of both Buddhist and non-Buddhist paths uphold various difficult and painful practices;
because of the grasping of views and so on, the VaibhÄá¹£ika and non-Buddhist people give rise to actions of dispute.

Here they themselves do not speak of the member of becoming, saying that grasping is a condition for actions and the becoming of karmic ripening. The Buddha also does not speak of the member of becoming apart from actions. Therefore what they say in total includes all conditioned grasping as a condition for becoming, contradicts what was said before and after, and is not in accord with the holy teachings.

The disciples of the Buddha do not speak words that contradict reason and the teachings in this way, and do not grasp and see as true what contradicts the teachings and reason, like the heretical schools.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that what accords with the teachings and reason, and all views that agree with reason and the teachings, they reject as false and mistaken, the same as the non-Buddhists.
Thus, when one praises oneself and disparages others, the wise hear this and deeply sigh with laughter.
Therefore, it was said before. Now, in this context, only the karma-existence that will explain the future results is taken, because it is the proximate cause. The principle is well established.
Only by karma-existence, from this life, one again forms the future birth, because it is not the retribution.
At the very moment of forming the birth existence, it is established as the member of birth.
In this birth, because of the condition of action, the initial moment of forming the birth existence is called the member of consciousness.
In this way, because of the condition of existence in the next life, the initial moment of forming the birth existence is called the member of birth.
This stage and this name are what is needed.

That is to say, in the present world, the function of consciousness is clear, and in the future world, the function of birth is most evident. According to the manifestation of one's own function, the name of the member is established.
Or, because another sÅ«tra says that birth is suffering, in order to cause those who create existence in the heavenly realms to give rise to disgust and abandon it, it is said to be birth.
Or, it is said that the karma of subsequent existence can all attract the result of suffering, in order to cause one to not create it.
Therefore, other sutras say that the ultimate cessation of the suffering of birth, etc. is called parinirvÄá¹‡a.
I do not say that birth is a name based on non-associated compositional factors. Therefore, the elder's rhetorical question is like crying alone in an empty and secluded place.
Also, the investigation of the characteristics of conditioned phenomena has already refuted that statement, so it is not repeated.
After the link of birth, up to the link of feeling, the intermediate states are collectively called old age and death.
Just as the four links of name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, and feeling in the present, in the future birth, these four states are called old age and death.
In order to cause one to abandon the mind that delights in future existence, the name old age and death is used to show the future faults.

If the consciousness of this world is the birth of the future, and the consciousness of the present is only the condition for the production of name-and-form, then birth would not be universal as the condition for old age and death.
Or, the name old age and death does not apply to the four periods of time. Therefore, the words old age and death should be further considered.
There is no error here, because the name member of old age and death definitely applies to the four periods of time, because it is possible for it to exist.
It is said that birth is a condition, because each member is called old age and death.
In the state of old age and death, it is said that there are four members, which manifest future birth, and also like the present, there is a sequence of cause and effect.
How do we know that the Buddha uses the word old age and death to generally refer to the four of name-and-form, etc. in the future?
Because the Buddha has already spoken of one member in the result of the subsequent period of dependent origination, only the remaining four.
In this way, it is correctly shown that in the three births, there are twelve members, with a wheel without a beginning.
If one speaks beyond this, it would be useless, because the meaning of the twelve members is already complete.
If one says that the future result should only speak of birth, and the meaning is already complete, it is useless to speak of the rest.
This is also unreasonable, because if only birth is mentioned, the effect in the subsequent period is not completely explained.
Just as in the past world, two members are causes that attract the effect in the present, which is completely explained.

In the same way, in the present world, three members are causes that attract the effect in the future, and it should also be completely explained, because it is to show the subsequent period as it is the prior period.
If it were otherwise, the teaching would be deficient, because the effect in the subsequent period is not completely explained.
Or the ignorant hear that if they are born in the worlds of the gods such as Vishnu, they will only have birth and no old age or death. Having heard this, they accumulate various wrong causes.
The Buddha explains that all birth has old age and death, in order to stop their seeking birth by these means, and therefore he does not merely speak of birth in regard to the future effect.
The elder says:
The World Honored One does not speak of the four members of the future with the term old age and death, because the name old age and death is not differentiated.
And because the scripture says up to death.
This explanation is unreasonable, because it has already been explained.
It has already been explained that the effect in the future includes one member, because only four remain.
Although the four members are different, the meaning of old age and death is common, so there is no error in speaking of them with one name.
In this way, it is shown that the causes and effects of the past and future are neither more nor less than twelve members.
If one establishes old age and death as a member beyond the four members, the explanation is too many, because there is nothing more to be explained.
It is also said to be too few, because it does not explain all.
Therefore, old age and death definitely includes the four members.
Up to death is also without error, because in the past, the effect of karma ends in death, and there is no old age and death beyond the four members.
The principle of the effect of karma in the future should also be so.

Except for the birth in the first state, the rest is called old age and death. Speaking of up to is said with reference to the final state, and it is not that at an earlier time it is not called old age and death.
Also, speaking of up to is said with reference to what definitely exists, because death definitely exists after the member of birth.
Therefore, their explanation is not acceptable.
Why are the characteristics of conditioned phenomena called the later end and its fruits, but not the earlier end?
Because there is a difference between what is directly perceived and not directly perceived.
The substance and arising, etc. of the fruits of the earlier end can both be directly perceived. By grasping their substance, one knows them.
The two kinds of later end are both not directly perceived. Only their faults are revealed in order to cause aversion and cessation of seeking.
As it is said:
Bhiká¹£us!
The arising, abiding, and production of form should be known as having the same meaning as the arising, abiding, and death of suffering. This is explained in detail.
Arising and death are each said to be one part, showing their functions and time periods are different.
Or the Buddha, in this meaning of dependent origination, speaks of worldly arising, etc., not speaking from the perspective of the highest truth.
The initial stage of arising is generally called birth, and the final stage is generally called death;
aging is not necessarily present. However, because it accords with death, it is not established as a separate part, and is generally called old age and death.
Or, when the aggregates increase, it is called birth, and when the aggregates decrease, it is called old age and death.
Or, the things that fools delight in are called birth, and the things that fools are disgusted with are called old age and death.
Therefore, birth and old age and death are each established as one member.
Isn't there also death conditioned by birth? Why is it only said that birth conditions death?
This is said because of certainty. That is to say, there are those who die but are not necessarily born. However, all those who are born are certain to die.
If that is so, then there is birth but it is not necessarily old age. Since old age here is based on the conventional, how can it be said that birth conditions old age?
This is because if there is no birth, there is definitely no old age, just as where there are no clouds, there is definitely no rain.

It is not that birth definitely arises immediately after death, because in the state of birth, it can arise immediately after. For this reason, the Buddha said that the dependent arising of sentient beings is endowed with twelve members, and the meaning is well established.
Furthermore, the various dependent originations are explained in four ways:
first, momentary; second, distant continuity; third, continuous bondage; fourth, state.
Some say that it shows the function of dharmas. Here, momentary means that cause and effect exist simultaneously, as a sutra says:
The eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, and so on.
Some other masters say:

In one moment, there are twelve links, which actually arise together. For example, in the mind that gives rise to karma together with craving, delusion is ignorance, volition is formation, the discrimination of various objects is consciousness, the three aggregates accompanying consciousness are collectively called name-and-form, the physical faculties are called the six sense bases, the contact associated with consciousness is called contact, the feeling associated with consciousness is called feeling, craving is craving, the various bonds associated with it are grasping, the two kinds of karma produced by it are becoming, and the arising of these dharmas is called birth, their maturation is called old age, and their destruction is called death.
The elder [Vasubandhu] says that this is unreasonable, because cause and effect do not exist in a single moment, because it contradicts the holy teachings, and because it is a definitive statement.
That is to say, cause and effect are definitely absent in the category of things that arise together. In the case of things that arise together, what is the cause and what is the effect?
Moreover, this statement contradicts the holy teachings. For example, the World-Honored One said to Ä€nanda:
If consciousness does not enter the mother's womb, can name-and-form come to form the kalala?
There are three kinds of action, and that which is called grasping in relation to feelings is said to be the cause of future existence.

I will teach you the increase and decrease of the Dharma, the practice leading to the origination of suffering and the practice leading to the cessation of suffering. This kind of practice cannot have origination or cessation, but is only due to the immeasurable faults of agitation, and the words of this kind are uttered lightly by those possessed by demons.
Moreover, this sÅ«tra is a definitive statement. The World-Honored One definitely says that this is the basis, because the Buddha himself explains it here.

This is not the orthodox opinion of this school, and even if it were, the objection is unreasonable, because a single moment also has the meaning of dependent origination, because the treatise is not composed solely for this purpose, because it has already been established, because it is explained in various ways, because it is said in the scriptures, and because it is not accepted.
It has been said that it is not only the twelve that are called dependent origination, because eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, etc., which is dependent origination.
How can the Sthavira not admit this?
Moreover, the treatise on a single moment of dependent origination is not expounded in order to establish simultaneous cause and effect, but only to show that dharmas should exist.

It has been said that in a single moment, the twelve members are all present and actually arise together. In this way, do the twelve arise by the power of mutual dependence, or do they arise by the power of prior causes?
This should be further considered.
Moreover, it has already been established that there is simultaneous cause, and the latter meaning should be further distinguished.

Moreover, the Buddha has expounded the meaning of dependent origination in various ways. One cannot simply disbelieve one and reject the others. In the sutras, he sometimes speaks of twelve factors, sometimes eleven, etc., as explained above.
The conditions for each factor are also explained differently. For example, some say that ignorance conditions formations;
some say that contact conditions formations, as in the Sutra of Understanding;
some say that craving conditions formations, as in the Karma Sutra;

some say that formations condition consciousness, some say that name-and-form conditions consciousness, some say that existence conditions consciousness, some say that the six sense bases condition contact, and some say that name-and-form conditions contact, as in the Sutra of Great Dependent Origination;
some say that two conditions contact, as a verse says: Eye and form, etc.

Some say that the three [sense-faculties, objects, and consciousnesses] are the conditions for contact. Some say that contact is the condition for feeling. Some say that the two [sense-faculties and objects] are the conditions for feeling. This is as stated in the above verse.
Some say that feeling is the condition for craving. Some say that contact is the condition for craving, as stated in the Sutra of Understanding.
Some say that ignorance is the condition for craving, as stated in the Karma Sutra.

That same sutra says that karma is the condition for the eye. Other sutras say that name-and-form is the condition for the eye. Still other sutras say that the great elements are the condition for the eye.
There are countless sutras like this, where the Buddha explains the various distinctions in dependent origination.
Therefore, the sutra cited by the elder also does not contradict this moment-to-moment dependent origination.
Because there is no contradiction in the principles stated by each.
Moreover, the Buddha himself explained moment-to-moment dependent origination, which is that in a single moment, many things rely on each other.
As a sutra says:
The eye and form are the conditions for the arising of defiled attention born of delusion.
The delusion in this is ignorance, the seeking of the deluded is called craving, and the activity of the one who craves is called action.
If it is said that consciousness, etc., are the substance of the other members, what principle or teaching is violated?
Since there is no violation, why not admit it?
Moreover, we do not admit that the SÅ«tra on Dependent Origination cited by them is definitive, and the characteristics of the non-definitive will be discussed later.
Even if we admit that that sÅ«tra is definitive, it does not contradict the dependent origination of a single moment.
The elder unreasonably dislikes this and says, Many faults, like demons, possess and cause this to be said lightly.
Now, in this context, we briefly explain their meaning according to the principles of the Abhidharma.
What is the basis for their previous statement that the twelve members are complete in a mind that gives rise to action together with craving?
Is it based on the mind that gives rise to the causes of giving rise to action, or is it based on the mind that gives rise to a single moment?

If the mind of initial impulse is based on the cause of the generation of action, and the cause of initial impulse is associated with anger and delusion, then there should be twelve members in full, because there is anger and delusion as the primary factor and craving as the secondary factor. It should not be said that the mind of initial impulse is only associated with craving.
If it is said that the mind of initial impulse is based on the generation of a single moment, and there is craving as the primary factor, why is it not discussed?
Some say:
It is based on the cause of initial impulse, because this is certain with regard to action.
In the action generated by craving as the primary factor, it is not certain that craving is the secondary factor, because a mind associated with anger and delusion may also be present.
We now say that this is based on the generation of a single moment. For this reason, it is said:

There is no bodily or verbal action that arises from the view of the realm of existence to be abandoned, which is generated by the cause of initial impulse. This is because the bodily and verbal action generated by the mind is apart from the generation of a single moment, and has not yet arisen.
If it were otherwise, when one raises the mind to commit an offense, at that time one would obtain the sin of immediate retribution.
Also, because the time of the arising of causes, etc., is distant, the turning of karma that is not loved is not definitely produced. Therefore, this is also not definite with regard to karma.
Therefore, it is definitely based on the arising of a moment and the arising of a moment as a condition.

In this way, one should understand the distant and continuous arising of conditions, which refers to the turning of the wheel from beginningless time due to the afflictions and karma that have results to be experienced in a later life and those that have results to be experienced in an indefinite life in the past and future.
As it is said, the origin of existence and love, etc., cannot be known.
Also, a verse should be said:
In the past, you and I together traveled the long road of birth and death,
Because we were unable to truly see the four noble truths.
The continuous arising of conditions refers to the arising of causes and effects of the same or different kinds that are related to each other without interruption.
As a sutra says:ğŸ”½Ignorance as a cause gives rise to attachment and defilement;
Because of understanding as a cause, the arising of non-attachment and non-defilement occurs.
Also, a sutra says:
From wholesome [karma] without interruption, defiled and indeterminate [karma] arises, or conversely.
As for conditioned arising in terms of states, it refers to the twelve five aggregates in the three periods of time, which manifest the power of dharmas without interruption.
As a sutra says:
Karma is the cause of birth, and craving is the cause of arising.
Among these five kinds of conditioned arising, what does the World-Honored One speak of?
Verse:
It is transmitted and allowed to be said in terms of states, and the name of a link is established based on the superior.
Treatise:
The masters of Abhidharma all say that the Buddha speaks of conditioned arising based on states.
The author of the sutra does not believe the words it is transmitted and allowed,
If all the links are fully endowed with the five aggregates, why are they only named ignorance, etc.?
Because in the various states, ignorance is superior, therefore based on the superior, the names ignorance, etc. are established.

That is to say, if in a certain state, ignorance is most superior, then the five aggregates in this state are collectively called ignorance, up to if in a certain state, old age and death are most superior, then the five aggregates in this state are collectively called old age and death.
Therefore, although the substance is general, there is no error in the specific names.
In this way, the five aggregates of the previous stage, as conditions, are generally able to induce the five aggregates of the later stage, as appropriate, and are all said to be all.
